verses.text: Ascribe to the LORD, O sons of God, ascribe to the LORD glory and strength.
verses.comment: The term 'sons of God' (Hebrew: 'bene elohim') can mean angelic beings, but also points to God's heavenly assembly—echoing divine council language seen elsewhere. Christians, by faith and baptism, are also adopted as sons of God (see Rom. 8:15), hinting at both little and great spiritual realities.

verses.text: Ascribe to the LORD the glory due His name; worship the LORD in holy splendor.
verses.comment: Worship in 'holy splendor' suggests liturgical worship: not just private prayer but a corporate, sacred offering, foreshadowing Christian worship that centers on the glory of God's name and holiness.

verses.text: The voice of the LORD is over the waters; the God of glory thunders, the LORD over the mighty waters.
verses.comment: Here, God's voice is depicted as powerful over the chaotic waters, reminiscent of Genesis 1 and Jesus' baptism, when the Father's voice came over the waters (Matt. 3:16-17). This alludes to both divine creation and new creation through Christ.

verses.text: The voice of the LORD is powerful; the voice of the LORD is full of majesty.
verses.comment: God's word is not merely informative, but effective and authoritative, a theme echoed in Hebrews 4:12: 'the word of God is living and active.' In Christian tradition, such language supports belief in the power of God's word, both written and proclaimed.

verses.text: The voice of the LORD breaks the cedars; the LORD breaks the cedars of Lebanon.
verses.comment: Cedars of Lebanon symbolize strength and earthly glory. God's word is shown to transcend all human power and splendor. Later, the cedar tree serves as a symbol for the Church (see Ezek. 17:22-24), rooted and made strong by God's own action.

verses.text: He makes them leap like a calf, Lebanon and Sirion like a young wild ox.
verses.comment: 'Lebanon' and 'Sirion' picture the mightiest mountains trembling at God's word. This demonstrates God's transcendence over creation—foreshadowing Christ's authority over both natural and spiritual realms (Mark 4:39).

verses.text: The voice of the LORD flashes forth flames of fire.
verses.comment: Fire is a symbol of God's presence (burning bush: Ex. 3:2) and of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost (Acts 2:3). The Psalm here anticipates God's ongoing action through visible signs.

verses.text: The voice of the LORD shakes the wilderness; the LORD shakes the wilderness of Kadesh.
verses.comment: Kadesh is a desert region where Israel wandered. God's voice moves history and prepares His people—echoing prophecies about preparing the way for the Lord (Isa. 40:3; Matt. 3:3).

verses.text: The voice of the LORD makes the deer give birth and strips the forests bare, and in His temple all cry, 'Glory!'
verses.comment: God's voice enhances both life and awe in creation, while worship in His 'temple' points to the people of God praising Him together in one holy place, foreshadowing the unified worship of believers.

verses.text: The LORD sits enthroned over the flood; the LORD sits enthroned as King forever.
verses.comment: God reigns not just in calm but even over the chaos ('flood'), suggesting His perpetual, sovereign kingship. This verse echoes the concept of an undivided, enduring kingdom that Christ inaugurates as King (Luke 1:33).

verses.text: The LORD gives strength to His people; the LORD blesses His people with peace.
verses.comment: Strength and peace are gifts only God can bestow—which, in Christian interpretation, come fully through Christ (see John 14:27: 'Peace I leave with you; my peace I give you'). This verse closes the Psalm with a promise fulfilled for God's gathered people through the new covenant.
